Worked Example 3
The numbers 1500 expressed as the product of their prime factors is 
𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏 = × 𝟑𝟑 × 𝟑𝟑. 
a) Explain whether 𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏 is a perfect square
b) Find the smallest whole number 𝒌𝒌, such that 𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏 is a perfect square.
c) Find the smallest whole number 𝒎𝒎, such that 𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏 is a perfect cube.
Solution
a) 1500 is not a perfect square because the powers of all the prime factors are not all divisible 
by 2.
b) 1500𝑘𝑘 = 22 × 3 × 53 × 𝑘𝑘 
22 × 3 × 53 × 𝑘𝑘 = 22 × 32 × 54 (22 × 32 × 54 is the nearest perfect square)
𝑘𝑘 = 22×32×54
22×3×53
𝑘𝑘 = 3 × 5 = 15
*Note that: 1500𝑘𝑘 = 22 × 3 × 53 × 𝑘𝑘 = (2 × 2) × (3) × (5 × 5 × 5) × 𝑘𝑘
We need (2 × 2) × (3) × (5 × 5 × 5) × 𝑘𝑘
to become (2 × 2) × (3 × 3) × (5 × 5 × 5 × 5) which is a perfect square.
since we are missing one 3 and one 5, 𝑘𝑘 will make up for the missing numbers and hence, 𝑘𝑘 =
3 × 5 = 15
c) 1500𝑚𝑚 = 22 × 3 × 53 × 𝑚𝑚 
22 × 3 × 53 × 𝑚𝑚 = 23 × 33 × 53
𝑚𝑚 = 23×33×53
22×3×53
𝑚𝑚 = 2 × 32 = 18
*Note that: 1500𝑚𝑚 = 22 × 3 × 53 × 𝑚𝑚 = (2 × 2) × (3) × (5 × 5 × 5) × 𝑚𝑚
We need (2 × 2) × (3) × (5 × 5 × 5) × 𝑚𝑚
to become (2 × 2 × 2) × (3 × 3 × 3) × (5 × 5 × 5) which is a perfect cube.
since we are missing one 2 and two 3s, 𝑚𝑚 will make up for the missing numbers and hence, 
𝑚𝑚 = 2 × 32 = 18

𝑝𝑝 is multiplied and 𝑞𝑞 is divided. This mean that 𝑝𝑝 will “add in” new factors

the 5.

Part 3: Highest Common Factor (HCF) and 
Lowest Common Multiple (LCM)
The highest common factor (HCF) of two or more numbers is the largest factor 
that is common to all the numbers.
The lowest common multiple (LCM) of two or more numbers is the smallest 
multiple that is common to all the numbers.
Worked Example 6
Find the Highest Common Factor (HCF) and Lowest Common Multiple
(LCM) of 1764, 270 and 1800.
Solution
Finding Highest Common Factor (HCF)
Prime factorize all 3 numbers:
1764 = 22 × 32 × 72
270 = 2 × 33 × 5
1800 = 23 × 32 × 52
(HCF: Select only factors that appear in all numbers and take the smallest power)
𝐻𝐻𝐻𝐻𝐻𝐻 = 2 × 32 = 18
Finding Lowest Common Multiple (LCM)
1764 = 22 × 32 × 72
270 = 2 × 33 × 5
1800 = 23 × 32 × 52
(LCM: select all factors and select the largest power for each)
𝑳𝑳𝑳𝑳𝑳𝑳 = 𝟑𝟑 × 𝟑𝟑𝟑𝟑 × × = 𝟐𝟐

Part 4: HCF/LCM Word Problems
Worked Example 8
boys and 𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏 girls signed up for a learning journey. The teacher wanted to divide 
them into mixed groups such that the number of boys in each group is the same and 
the number of girls in each group is the same.
i) Find the largest possible number of groups in this learning journey
ii) Hence, find the number of boys in each group.
Solution
i) The number of groups will be a common factor of both 84 and 100 since we are divinding all of 
the students into groups.
Since we want the largest possible number of groups, we are looking for the highest common factor 
(HCF).
84 = 22 × 3 × 7
100 = 22 × 52
HCF = 22 = 4
The largest possible number of groups if 4. 
*Note: The world “largest” in the question hints to us we are looking for the “highest” common factor.
ii) 84 boys divided into 4 groups.
84
4 = 21
There are 21 boys in each group.
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 23 / 34>

Unauthorized copying and distribution prohibited. Copyright © www.tuitionmath.com. All rights reserved 23
Worked Example 9
On an electric advertisement screen, its background image of a snowy mountain 
lights up once every 64 seconds. The image of a man and that of a large bottle of beer 
light up once every 30 seconds and 16 seconds respectively. Calculate the interval, in 
minutes, at which all three images light up at the same time.
Solution
The time taken for all 3 to light up at the same time will be a common multiple of 64,30 and 
16.
16 = 24
30 = 2 × 3 × 5
64 = 26
𝐿𝐿 = 26 × 3 × 5 = 960
960 seconds = 960

Worked Example 10
The highest common factor and the lowest common multiple of three numbers are 
× 𝟑𝟑 and 𝟑𝟑 × 𝟑𝟑 × respectively. Given that two of the numbers are 36 and 180, 
find the smallest possible value of the third number.
Solution
Let the third number be 𝑦𝑦.
36 = 22 × 32
180 = 22 × 32 × 5
𝑦𝑦 = ___________________
HCF = 22 × 3
LCM = 23 × 32 × 5 
Using Logic :
𝑦𝑦 must include a minimum of 22 × 3 because that is the HCF.
𝑦𝑦 must include 23 since the LCM has 23 but the other two numbers do not.
𝑦𝑦 does not need 32 since the other numbers already contain it.
𝑦𝑦 does not need to include 5 since the other numbers already contain it .
Hence, the smallest possible value of the third number is:
23 × 3 = 24

Part 6: Others
Worked Example 11
Liu has 𝟏𝟏 one-centimetre cubes. He arranges all of the cubes into a cuboid. The 
perimeter of the top of the cuboid is 22cm. Each side of the cuboid has a length 
greater than 2 cm. Find the height of the cuboid.
Solution
Firstly, understand that if all the cubes are 1 𝑐𝑐𝑚𝑚3, it implies that 144 𝑐𝑐𝑚𝑚3 is the volume of the 
final cuboid.
Secondly, realize that prime factorization is going to be a useful tool to determine the dimension 
of the cuboid.
144 = 24 × 32
144 = 2 × 2 × 2 × 2 × 3 × 3
Let the three dimensions of the cuboid be 𝑥𝑥, 𝑦𝑦 and 𝑧𝑧
Note that the dimensions of the cuboid will be made up of multiples of the prime factors 
(no more, no less. Exactly four 2s and two 3s). So we can only pick factors of 𝑥𝑥, 𝑦𝑦, 𝑧𝑧 from 
the four 2s and the two 3s available.
Since the perimeter of the top surface is 22cm (i.e. 2𝑥𝑥 + 2𝑦𝑦 = 22), that means two of the 
dimensions (𝑥𝑥 + 𝑦𝑦) must add up to be 11cm.
Trial and Error 1:
One possible way is to let 𝑥𝑥 = 3 × 3 and 𝑦𝑦 = 2 and the remaining 2 × 2 × 2 = 𝑧𝑧
Since 𝑥𝑥 + 𝑦𝑦 = 9 + 2 = 11 satisfies the criteria for perimeter of 22.
However, the question has a criteria that the lengths must be greater than 2. So this will 
not work.
Trial and Error 2:
Let 𝑥𝑥 = 2 × 2 × 2 = 8 and 𝑦𝑦 = 3 and 𝑧𝑧 = 2 × 3 = 6
Since 𝑥𝑥 + 𝑦𝑦 = 8 + 3 = 11 and all the lengths are greater than 2. This dimensions satisfies 
all the criteria. 
Therefore, the height is 6𝑐𝑐 .

content.text:
import math
def factor(n):
    return sp.factorint(n)
def gcd(*nums):
    from math import gcd
    g=0
    for n in nums:
        g=math.gcd(g,n)
    return g
def lcm(a,b):
    return abs(a*b)//math.gcd(a,b)
def lcmm(*nums):
    from functools import reduce
    return reduce(lambda x,y: lcm(x,y), nums)
# verify answers
print("Q1 gcd", gcd(84,156))
print("Q2 gcd", gcd(144,180,240))
print("Q3 lcm", lcmm(48,180))
print("Q4 lcm", lcmm(72,90,150))
# Q5 compute for A,B,C
A=2**3*3**2*5
B=2**2*3**4*7
C=2**4*3*5**2
print(A,B,C, gcd(A,B,C), lcmm(A,B,C))
# Q6
print("factor 504", factor(504))
print("Q6 gcd", gcd(720,504), "lcm", lcmm(720,504))
# Q7
print("Q7 k for 900 cube? we claim 30", factor(900*30), round((900*30)**(1/3),4))
# check cube
cube=int(round((900*30)**(1/3)))
print(cube, cube**3)
print("Q7 m 315 square", factor(315*35), int(math.isqrt(315*35))**2==315*35)
print("gcd", gcd(900,315),"lcm", lcmm(900,315))
# Q8
print("gcd", gcd(450,672),"lcm", lcmm(450,672), "n", lcmm(450,672)//450)
# Q9
print("factor 756", factor(756))
# t square=21 cube=98 verify
print("756*21 square?", int(math.isqrt(756*21))**2==756*21, math.isqrt(756*21))
# cube check
print("756*98 cube?", round((756*98)**(1/3),5))
cube=int(round((756*98)**(1/3)))
print(cube, cube**3==756*98)
# Q10
print("factor 630", factor(630))
print("630*70", 630*70, math.isqrt(630*70), int(math.isqrt(630*70))**2==630*70)
# Q11
print("factor 540", factor(540))
print("540/20", 540//20)
# Q12
print("360 factors", factor(360))
# Q13
print("gcd", gcd(588,756),"lcm", lcmm(588,756), "n", lcmm(588,756)//588)
# Q14
print("gcd 1260,840", gcd(1260,840), "lcm", lcmm(1260,840))
# largest square divisor of 1260
n=1260
f=factor(n)
sq=1
for p,e in f.items():
    sq*=p**(e//2*2) # largest even exponent <= e
sq

parts:
Below are 15 new questions modeled on **Section 3 (Part 3: Highest common factor and lowest common multiple)**—same “compute HCF/LCM”, “leave answers in index form”, and “hence find smallest integer …” styles. fileciteturn1file0L37-L45 fileciteturn1file3L3-L38

## Practice Questions (Section 3 style)

**1)** Find the **highest common factor (HCF)** of 84 and 156.

**2)** Find the HCF of 144, 180 and 240.

**3)** Find the **lowest common multiple (LCM)** of 48 and 180.

**4)** Find the LCM of 72, 90 and 150.

**5)** Find the HCF and LCM of the following, **leaving your answers in index form**:  
\(2^3 \times 3^2 \times 5,\;\; 2^2 \times 3^4 \times 7,\;\; 2^4 \times 3 \times 5^2\).

**6)** Given that \(720 = 2^4 \times 3^2 \times 5\).  
a) Express 504 as a product of prime factors (index form).  
b) Hence, find the HCF and LCM of 720 and 504.

**7)** The numbers 900 and 315, written as the product of prime factors, are  
\(900=2^2\times 3^2\times 5^2\) and \(315=3^2\times 5\times 7\). Hence, find  
a) the smallest integer \(k\) such that \(900k\) is a perfect cube,  
b) the smallest integer \(m\) such that \(315m\) is a perfect square,  
c) the largest integer which is a factor of both 900 and 315,  
d) the smallest integer which is divisible by both 900 and 315.

**8)** The numbers 450 and 672 are given.  
a) Find their HCF and LCM.  
b) Hence, find the smallest positive integer \(n\) such that \(450n\) is a multiple of 672.

**9)**  
a) Express 756 as a product of prime factors (index form).  
b) Find the smallest positive integer \(t\) such that \(756t\) is a perfect square.  
c) Find the smallest positive integer \(u\) such that \(756u\) is a perfect cube.

**10)** Find the smallest positive integer \(p\) such that \(\sqrt{630p}\) is a whole number. Hence, find \(\sqrt{630p}\).

**11)** Find the smallest positive integer \(q\) such that \(\dfrac{540}{q}\) is a perfect cube. (State \(q\) and the cube.)

**12)** Find the smallest integers \(x\) and \(y\) such that \(2^x \times 3^y \times 5^2\) is a multiple of 360.

**13)** Given that \(588 = 2^2 \times 3 \times 7^2\) and \(756 = 2^2 \times 3^3 \times 7\).  
a) Find the HCF and LCM, leaving answers in index form.  
b) Find the smallest positive integer \(n\) such that \(588n\) is a multiple of 756.

**14)** The numbers 1260 and 840 are given.  
a) Find the HCF and LCM.  
b) Find the smallest positive integer \(k\) such that \(\dfrac{1260}{k}\) is a perfect square.  
c) Find the smallest positive integer \(m\) such that \(840m\) is a perfect cube. (Leave \(m\) in prime factors.)

**15)** Let \(N = 2^3 \times 3 \times 5^2 \times 7^3\).  
Find the smallest positive integer \(k\) such that \(Nk\) is **both** a perfect square and a perfect cube. (Leave \(k\) in index form.)

---

## Answers (concise)

**1)** HCF \(=12\)

**2)** HCF \(=12\)

**3)** LCM \(=720\)

**4)** LCM \(=1800\)

**5)** HCF \(=2^2\times 3\).  
LCM \(=2^4\times 3^4\times 5^2\times 7\) \((=226800)\).

**6)** a) \(504=2^3\times 3^2\times 7\).  
b) HCF \(=72\), LCM \(=5040\).

**7)** a) \(k=30\).  
b) \(m=35\).  
c) HCF \(=45\).  
d) LCM \(=6300\).

**8)** a) HCF \(=6\), LCM \(=50400\).  
b) \(n=\dfrac{\text{LCM}}{450}= \dfrac{50400}{450}=112\).

**9)** a) \(756=2^2\times 3^3\times 7\).  
b) \(t=21\).  
c) \(u=98\).

**10)** \(p=70\), and \(\sqrt{630p}=\sqrt{44100}=210\).

**11)** \(q=20\), and \(\dfrac{540}{20}=27=3^3\).

**12)** \(x=3,\; y=2\).

**13)** a) HCF \(=2^2\times 3\times 7\), LCM \(=2^2\times 3^3\times 7^2\).  
b) \(n=\dfrac{\text{LCM}}{588}=\dfrac{5292}{588}=9\).

**14)** a) HCF \(=420\), LCM \(=2520\).  
b) \(k=35\) (since \(1260/35=36\)).  
c) \(m=3^2\times 5^2\times 7^2\) \((=11025)\).

**15)** Need all powers to become multiples of 6, so  
\[
k=2^3\times 3^5\times 5^4\times 7^3.
\]

If you want, I can re-balance the set to be *more* like 3A (pure HCF/LCM) or *more* like 3B (more “perfect square/cube / division / square root” hybrids).

[L145] Worked Example 5
[L146] 𝒑𝒑 and 𝒒𝒒 are prime numbers. Find the smallest values of 𝒑𝒑 and 𝒒𝒒 so 
[L147] that 𝟑𝟑 × 𝒑𝒑
[L148] 𝒒𝒒 is a perfect cube.
[L149] Solution
[L150] Prime Factorize 360 = 23 × 32 × 5
[L151] 360𝑝𝑝
[L152] 𝑞𝑞 = 23×32 ×5×𝑝𝑝
[L153] 𝑞𝑞
[L154] 𝑝𝑝 is multiplied and 𝑞𝑞 is divided. This mean that 𝑝𝑝 will “add in” new factors 
[L155] while 𝑞𝑞 will “remove” factors. 
[L156] Notice that 23 is already a perfect cube. Nothing needs to be done to it.
[L157] 32 is one more 3 away from being a perfect cube. So it is easier to “add in” 
[L158] one more 3.
[L159] 5 is two more 5s away from being a perfect cube. So it is easier to “remove” 
[L160] the 5.
[L161] Hence, 𝑝𝑝 = 3 and 𝑞𝑞 = 5

[L252] Part 3: Highest Common Factor (HCF) and 
[L253] Lowest Common Multiple (LCM)
[L254] The highest common factor (HCF) of two or more numbers is the largest factor 
[L255] that is common to all the numbers.
[L256] The lowest common multiple (LCM) of two or more numbers is the smallest 
[L257] multiple that is common to all the numbers.
[L258] Worked Example 6
[L259] Find the Highest Common Factor (HCF) and Lowest Common Multiple
[L260] (LCM) of 1764, 270 and 1800.
[L261] Solution
[L262] Finding Highest Common Factor (HCF)
[L263] Prime factorize all 3 numbers:
[L264] 1764 = 22 × 32 × 72
[L265] 270 = 2 × 33 × 5
[L266] 1800 = 23 × 32 × 52
[L267] (HCF: Select only factors that appear in all numbers and take the smallest power)
[L268] 𝐻𝐻𝐻𝐻𝐻𝐻 = 2 × 32 = 18
[L269] Finding Lowest Common Multiple (LCM)
[L270] 1764 = 22 × 32 × 72
[L271] 270 = 2 × 33 × 5
[L272] 1800 = 23 × 32 × 52
[L273] (LCM: select all factors and select the largest power for each)
[L274] 𝑳𝑳𝑳𝑳𝑳𝑳 = 𝟑𝟑 × 𝟑𝟑𝟑𝟑 × × = 𝟐𝟐

[L380] Worked Example 8
[L381] boys and 𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏𝟏 girls signed up for a learning journey. The teacher wanted to divide 
[L382] them into mixed groups such that the number of boys in each group is the same and 
[L383] the number of girls in each group is the same.
[L384] i) Find the largest possible number of groups in this learning journey
[L385] ii) Hence, find the number of boys in each group.
[L386] Solution
[L387] i) The number of groups will be a common factor of both 84 and 100 since we are divinding all of 
[L388] the students into groups.
[L389] Since we want the largest possible number of groups, we are looking for the highest common factor 
[L390] (HCF).
[L391] 84 = 22 × 3 × 7
[L392] 100 = 22 × 52
[L393] HCF = 22 = 4
[L394] The largest possible number of groups if 4. 
[L395] *Note: The world “largest” in the question hints to us we are looking for the “highest” common factor.
[L396] ii) 84 boys divided into 4 groups.
[L397] 84
[L398] 4 = 21
[L399] There are 21 boys in each group.

[L405] light up once every 30 seconds and 16 seconds respectively. Calculate the interval, in 
[L406] minutes, at which all three images light up at the same time.

[L411] 30 = 2 × 3 × 5

[L474] Worked Example 10
[L475] The highest common factor and the lowest common multiple of three numbers are 
[L476] × 𝟑𝟑 and 𝟑𝟑 × 𝟑𝟑 × respectively. Given that two of the numbers are 36 and 180, 
[L477] find the smallest possible value of the third number.

[L479] Let the third number be 𝑦𝑦.
[L480] 36 = 22 × 32
[L481] 180 = 22 × 32 × 5
[L482] 𝑦𝑦 = ___________________

[L484] LCM = 23 × 32 × 5 
[L485] Using Logic :
[L486] 𝑦𝑦 must include a minimum of 22 × 3 because that is the HCF.
[L487] 𝑦𝑦 must include 23 since the LCM has 23 but the other two numbers do not.
[L488] 𝑦𝑦 does not need 32 since the other numbers already contain it.
[L489] 𝑦𝑦 does not need to include 5 since the other numbers already contain it .
[L490] Hence, the smallest possible value of the third number is:
[L491] 23 × 3 = 24

[L518] Part 6: Others
[L519] Worked Example 11
[L520] Liu has 𝟏𝟏 one-centimetre cubes. He arranges all of the cubes into a cuboid. The 
[L521] perimeter of the top of the cuboid is 22cm. Each side of the cuboid has a length 
[L522] greater than 2 cm. Find the height of the cuboid.
[L523] Solution
[L524] Firstly, understand that if all the cubes are 1 𝑐𝑐𝑚𝑚3, it implies that 144 𝑐𝑐𝑚𝑚3 is the volume of the 
[L525] final cuboid.
[L526] Secondly, realize that prime factorization is going to be a useful tool to determine the dimension 
[L527] of the cuboid.
[L528] 144 = 24 × 32
[L529] 144 = 2 × 2 × 2 × 2 × 3 × 3
[L530] Let the three dimensions of the cuboid be 𝑥𝑥, 𝑦𝑦 and 𝑧𝑧
[L531] Note that the dimensions of the cuboid will be made up of multiples of the prime factors 
[L532] (no more, no less. Exactly four 2s and two 3s). So we can only pick factors of 𝑥𝑥, 𝑦𝑦, 𝑧𝑧 from 
[L533] the four 2s and the two 3s available.
[L534] Since the perimeter of the top surface is 22cm (i.e. 2𝑥𝑥 + 2𝑦𝑦 = 22), that means two of the 
[L535] dimensions (𝑥𝑥 + 𝑦𝑦) must add up to be 11cm.
[L536] Trial and Error 1:
[L537] One possible way is to let 𝑥𝑥 = 3 × 3 and 𝑦𝑦 = 2 and the remaining 2 × 2 × 2 = 𝑧𝑧
[L538] Since 𝑥𝑥 + 𝑦𝑦 = 9 + 2 = 11 satisfies the criteria for perimeter of 22.
[L539] However, the question has a criteria that the lengths must be greater than 2. So this will 
[L540] not work.
[L541] Trial and Error 2:
[L542] Let 𝑥𝑥 = 2 × 2 × 2 = 8 and 𝑦𝑦 = 3 and 𝑧𝑧 = 2 × 3 = 6
[L543] Since 𝑥𝑥 + 𝑦𝑦 = 8 + 3 = 11 and all the lengths are greater than 2. This dimensions satisfies 
[L544] all the criteria. 
[L545] Therefore, the height is 6𝑐𝑐 .
[L546] <PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 32 / 34>

content.text:
import math, functools
def gcd(*nums):
    return functools.reduce(math.gcd, nums)
def lcm(a,b):
    return abs(a*b)//math.gcd(a,b)
def lcm_many(*nums):
    return functools.reduce(lcm, nums, 1)
# Q1: 132,210
print("Q1 HCF", gcd(132,210))
# Q2: 864,1056,720
print("Q2 HCF", gcd(864,1056,720))
# Q3: lcm 50,80,95
print("Q3 LCM seconds", lcm_many(50,80,95))
# Q4: lcm 72,90,108
print("Q4 LCM seconds", lcm_many(72,90,108))
# Q5: lcm 60,84,210
print("Q5 LCM years", lcm_many(60,84,210))
# Q6: HCF 480,750
print("Q6 HCF cm", gcd(480,750))
# Q7 HCF 360,420,540
print("Q7 HCF cm", gcd(360,420,540))
# Q8 LCM 96,120,150
print("Q8 LCM sec", lcm_many(96,120,150))
# Q9 LCM 18,24,45 minutes
print("Q9 LCM min", lcm_many(18,24,45))
# Q10 LCM 6,8,15
print("Q10 LCM", lcm_many(6,8,15))
# Q11 LCM 6,9,15,18,24
print("Q11 LCM share", lcm_many(6,9,15,18,24))
# Q12 LCM 12,18,20
print("Q12 LCM", lcm_many(12,18,20))
# Q13 LCM 9,14,21
print("Q13 LCM", lcm_many(9,14,21))
# Q15 HCF 168,252,420
print("Q15 HCF", gcd(168,252,420))

Below are 15 new questions modeled on **Section 4 / Part 4: HCF–LCM word problems** (grouping/packing → HCF; “together again / same time” cycles → LCM; tiling/cutting/no leftover; remainder-style packing; stacking to equal height). fileciteturn3file0L377-L415 fileciteturn3file0L418-L453

---

## Practice Questions (Section 4 style)

**1)** **132 boys** and **210 girls** signed up for a camp. They are to be divided into mixed groups such that the number of boys in each group is the same and the number of girls in each group is the same.  
i) Find the **largest possible number of groups**.  
ii) Hence, find the number of boys in each group.  
iii) Hence, find the number of girls in each group.

**2)** A company packs **864** boxes of snacks, **1056** bottles of water and **720** sandwiches into as many goodie bags as possible. Each goodie bag must have the same contents.  
a) What is the **maximum number of goodie bags** that can be prepared?  
b) How many of each item are in each goodie bag?

**3)** Three traffic lights will turn red at fixed intervals of **50 s**, **1 min 20 s**, and **1 min 35 s** respectively. They all turn red simultaneously at **09 15 00**. Find the **next time** when they will turn red simultaneously again.

**4)** Three school bells ring at fixed intervals of **1 min 12 s**, **1 min 30 s**, and **1 min 48 s** respectively. They ring together at **14 12**. Find the next time they will ring together again.

**5)** Three comets pass through our solar system every **60 years**, **84 years** and **210 years** respectively. They were last seen together in the year **1900**. In which year will they be seen together again?

**6)** The floor of a hall is **4.8 m by 7.5 m** and is to be laid with identical square tiles.  
a) Find the **largest possible** side length (in cm) of each tile.  
b) Find the **number of tiles** needed.

**7)** A contractor has ropes of lengths **3.6 m**, **4.2 m** and **5.4 m**. He wants to cut them into equal pieces of the **greatest possible length**, with no leftover.  
a) Find the length of each piece in cm.  
b) Find how many pieces can be cut from each rope.

**8)** Three toy cars \(A,B,C\) start at the same point on a circular track. They take **96 s**, **120 s**, and **150 s** respectively to complete one round. The race starts at **09 50**.  
a) At what time will they next meet at the start point again?  
b) How many rounds has car \(A\) completed by then?

**9)** Three buses arrive at a bus stop every **18 min**, **24 min**, and **45 min** respectively. They arrive together at **08 20**. Find the next time they will arrive together again.

**10)** A bakery has some tarts. There are **always 5 tarts left over** whether the tarts are packed into boxes of **6**, **8** or **15**. What is the **minimum possible** number of tarts?

**11)** A ribbon is shared equally among **5** tailors. They cut their ribbon into **6 cm**, **9 cm**, **15 cm**, **18 cm**, and **24 cm** pieces respectively. To avoid wastage, each tailor must have **no leftover** after cutting. Find the **total length** of the original ribbon (in cm).

**12)** Cylindrical cans \(A,B,C\) (same radii) have heights **12 cm**, **18 cm**, and **20 cm** respectively. They are stacked (using only one type per stack) to reach the same height.  
a) Find the **minimum common height**.  
b) Find the **minimum number of \(B\)** cans required.

**13)** Boxes \(P,Q,R\) have heights **9 cm**, **14 cm**, and **21 cm** respectively. They are stacked to form towers of equal height.  
a) Find the **minimum height** of each tower.  
b) Find the **minimum number of \(Q\)** boxes needed.

**14)** Three robot arms repeat a cycle every **12 s**, **18 s**, and **30 s** respectively. They begin a cycle together at **16 05 30**.  
a) When will they next begin a cycle together?  
b) How many cycles will the **12 s** arm complete by that time?

**15)** A charity wants to pack **168** bottles, **252** food packs and **420** masks into as many identical care packs as possible, with none left over.  
a) Find the **maximum number of care packs**.  
b) State the contents of each care pack.

---

## Answers (very concise)

**1)** HCF\((132,210)=6\).  
i) 6 groups  
ii) \(132/6=22\) boys  
iii) \(210/6=35\) girls

**2)** HCF\((864,1056,720)=48\).  
a) 48 bags  
b) \(864/48=18\) boxes, \(1056/48=22\) bottles, \(720/48=15\) sandwiches

**3)** LCM\((50,80,95)=7600\) s \(=2\) h \(6\) min \(40\) s.  
Next time: **11 21 40**

**4)** LCM\((72,90,108)=1080\) s \(=18\) min.  
Next time: **14 30**

**5)** LCM\((60,84,210)=420\).  
Year \(1900+420=\) **2320**

**6)** Convert: \(4.8\text{ m}=480\text{ cm},\;7.5\text{ m}=750\text{ cm}\).  
a) HCF\((480,750)=30\) cm  
b) \((480/30)(750/30)=16\times25=\) **400 tiles**

**7)** Convert: \(360,420,540\) cm.  
a) HCF\((360,420,540)=60\) cm  
b) \(360/60=6,\;420/60=7,\;540/60=9\)

**8)** LCM\((96,120,150)=2400\) s \(=40\) min.  
a) **10 30**  
b) \(2400/96=25\) rounds

**9)** LCM\((18,24,45)=360\) min \(=6\) h.  
Next time: **14 20**

**10)** LCM\((6,8,15)=120\). Minimum \(=120+5=\) **125**

**11)** Each share must be LCM\((6,9,15,18,24)=360\) cm.  
Total \(=5\times360=\) **1800 cm**

**12)** a) LCM\((12,18,20)=180\) cm  
b) \(180/18=10\)

**13)** a) LCM\((9,14,21)=126\) cm  
b) \(126/14=9\)

**14)** a) LCM\((12,18,30)=180\) s \(=3\) min → **16 08 30**  
b) \(180/12=15\) cycles

**15)** HCF\((168,252,420)=84\).  
a) 84 packs  
b) \(168/84=2\) bottles, \(252/84=3\) food packs, \(420/84=5\) masks

---  

If you want these to skew **harder**, I can add variants where the “together again” time must be expressed in **hours + minutes**, or where the “leftover” condition uses a nontrivial remainder (still within the same pedagogy).

parts:
## Section 3 (HCF / LCM) — 10 easy-to-medium questions

**1)** Find the HCF of 36 and 84.  
**2)** Find the LCM of 12 and 18.  
**3)** Find the HCF of 45, 60 and 75.  
**4)** Find the LCM of 20, 30 and 24.  
**5)** Find the HCF and LCM of \(2^3\!\times\!3^2\) and \(2^2\!\times\!3^4\!\times\!5\), leaving answers in index form.  
**6)** (a) Express 168 as a product of prime factors (index form). (b) Hence find the HCF and LCM of 168 and 210.  
**7)** Find the smallest integer \(k\) such that \(72k\) is a perfect square. Hence find \(\sqrt{72k}\).  
**8)** Find the smallest integer \(m\) such that \(54m\) is a perfect cube. Hence write \(54m\) as a cube.  
**9)** Find the smallest integer \(n\) such that \(90n\) is a multiple of 144.  
**10)** Find the smallest integer \(q\) such that \(360q\) is a perfect square. Hence find \(\sqrt{360q}\).

### Answers (very concise)
1) \(12\) (HCF)  
2) \(36\) (LCM)  
3) \(15\) (HCF)  
4) \(120\) (LCM)  
5) HCF \(=2^2\!\times\!3^2\), LCM \(=2^3\!\times\!3^4\!\times\!5\)  
6) (a) \(168=2^3\!\times\!3\!\times\!7\)  (b) HCF \(=42\), LCM \(=840\)  
7) \(k=2\), \(\sqrt{72k}=\sqrt{144}=12\)  
8) \(m=4\), \(54m=216=6^3\)  
9) \(n=8\) (since \(90\cdot 8=720=144\cdot 5\))  
10) \(q=10\), \(\sqrt{360q}=\sqrt{3600}=60\)

---

## Section 4 (Word problems) — 10 easy-to-medium questions

**1)** 48 apples and 60 oranges are packed into identical bags with no leftovers.  
a) Find the maximum number of bags. b) Find the number of apples and oranges per bag.

**2)** 84 red beads and 126 blue beads are used to make identical necklaces (all beads used).  
a) Maximum number of necklaces? b) Red and blue beads per necklace?

**3)** Three bells ring every 15 min, 20 min and 30 min. They ring together at **09:10**. When is the next time they ring together?

**4)** Two lights flash every 24 s and 36 s. They flash together at **14:05:00**. When will they next flash together?

**5)** A rectangular floor is \(3.6\text{ m} \times 2.4\text{ m}\). It is tiled with identical square tiles (largest possible).  
a) Tile side length (cm). b) Number of tiles.

**6)** Ropes of length 2.1 m and 3.5 m are cut into equal pieces of greatest possible length (no leftover).  
a) Length of each piece (cm). b) Number of pieces from each rope.

**7)** A hall has \(N\) chairs. When arranged in rows of 6 or rows of 8, there are always 2 chairs left over. Find the least possible \(N\).

**8)** Three buses arrive every 12 min, 18 min and 30 min. They arrive together at **07:40**. Find the next time they arrive together.

**9)** Boxes of height 6 cm and 10 cm are stacked (separately) to the same height.  
a) Minimum common height. b) Number of 6 cm boxes and 10 cm boxes.

**10)** Ribbons of 90 cm, 120 cm and 150 cm are cut into equal pieces of greatest possible length (no leftover).  
a) Length of each piece. b) Number of pieces from each ribbon.

### Answers (very concise)
1) HCF\((48,60)=12\) → a) 12 bags b) 4 apples, 5 oranges  
2) HCF\((84,126)=42\) → a) 42 necklaces b) 2 red, 3 blue  
3) LCM\((15,20,30)=60\) min → **10:10**  
4) LCM\((24,36)=72\) s → **14:06:12**  
5) \(360,240\) cm → HCF \(=120\) cm; tiles \(=(360/120)(240/120)=3\cdot 2=6\)  
6) \(210,350\) cm → HCF \(=70\) cm; pieces: \(210/70=3,\;350/70=5\)  
7) \(N\equiv 2\pmod 6,\; N\equiv 2\pmod 8\Rightarrow N-2\) multiple of LCM\((6,8)=24\) → least \(N=26\)  
8) LCM\((12,18,30)=180\) min \(=3\) h → **10:40**  
9) LCM\((6,10)=30\) cm → 5 boxes of 6 cm; 3 boxes of 10 cm  
10) HCF\((90,120,150)=30\) cm → pieces: \(3,\;4,\;5\) respectively

parts:
According to a document (no publication date is shown in the PDF excerpts), **yes**—Sections **5** and **6** contain question types that we have **not** yet reflected in our Sections 3/4-style sets.

### 1) Section 5 introduces “reverse HCF/LCM” questions (new)
These are problems where you’re **given the HCF and LCM** (of **two** or **three** numbers) plus partial information, and must **deduce the missing number(s)**—often with constraints like “smallest possible,” “two possible values,” or “numbers within a range.” Examples include:
- Given **HCF and LCM of three numbers** and **two of the numbers**, find the **smallest possible** third number. 【59:0†1) HCF LCM.pdf†L12-L31】
- A full set of self-practice variants: smallest possible third number; two possible third numbers; find two numbers given HCF/LCM and bounds; solve for \(x\) given HCF/LCM; find smallest \(x\) in an interval given HCF; find \(p,q\) given HCF/LCM and bounds. 【59:0†1) HCF LCM.pdf†L32-L46】【59:9†1) HCF LCM.pdf†L3-L18】

These **do not appear** in Sections 3/4, which focus on **forward** computation of HCF/LCM and direct applications (grouping/cycles/tiling etc.).

### 2) Section 6 introduces “unit cubes → cuboid dimensions” problems (new)
These use **prime factorisation / factor triples** (not HCF/LCM directly) to determine **cuboid dimensions** from:
- the **number of 1 cm³ cubes** (volume),
- the **perimeter of the top face**,
- and side-length constraints (e.g., each side \(>2\) cm). 【59:9†1) HCF LCM.pdf†L22-L36】【59:12†1) HCF LCM.pdf†L1-L12】
Self-practice in this section includes “given \(595\) cubes find dimensions,” “given \(168\) cubes with side constraints find side counts,” and “given \(540\) cubes + top perimeter find dimensions.” 【59:12†1) HCF LCM.pdf†L14-L21】

---

If you want, I can generate two new question sets mirroring **Section 5 (reverse HCF/LCM)** and **Section 6 (cuboid/cubes)** in the same pedagogy, with concise answer keys.
